content.p: Socrates, a classical Greek philosopher credited as one of the founders of Western philosophy, remains an enigmatic figure known chiefly through the accounts of later classical writers, especially his students Plato and Xenophon. He lived in Athens from 470 BC until his death in 399 BC, during a time of great intellectual and cultural growth.

Socrates' approach to philosophy involved a method of questioning now known as the Socratic Method, aimed at stimulating critical thinking and illuminating ideas. His technique involves asking a series of questions to challenge assumptions and reveal underlying beliefs. This method has deeply influenced the Western logical and ethical thinking framework.

Unlike many philosophers of his time who focused on metaphysical topics, Socrates directed his inquiries toward human issues, particularly ethics and the pursuit of virtue. He believed that knowledge was inherently connected to virtue, positing that the truly wise are virtuous and that wrongdoing is a result of ignorance.

In 399 BC, Socrates was brought to trial, accused of corrupting the youth of Athens and impiety. His refusal to retreat from his principles led to his conviction. Socrates chose to accept his death sentence, drinking a cup of poison hemlock in a display of philosophical and ethical consistency, thereby cementing his legacy as a martyr for truth and intellectual integrity.
